articles.headline: Hedge Fund Manager Who Plays His Cards Right
articles.snippet: After entering the World Series of Poker on a whim, David Einhorn won more than $650,000 and gave all his winnings to charity.
articles.abstract: After entering the World Series of Poker on a whim, David Einhorn won more than $650,000 and gave all his winnings to charity.

articles.headline: Terror Plot Foiled; Airports Quickly Clamp Down
articles.snippet: British officials arrested 24 men, but said they believed that some plotters were probably still at large, requiring increased airport security.
articles.abstract: British officials arrested 24 men, but said they believed that some plotters were probably still at large, requiring increased airport security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: Israel Asks U.S. to Ship Rockets With Wide Blast
articles.snippet: Some officials have sought to delay the approval because of concerns over the likelihood of civilian casualties.
articles.abstract: Some officials have sought to delay the approval because of concerns over the likelihood of civilian casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 — Israel has asked the Bush administration to speed delivery of short-range antipersonnel rockets armed with cluster munitions, which it could use to strike Hezbollah missile sites in Lebanon, two American officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: A Brief Recovery and Now This
articles.snippet: The foiled terrorist plot in London throws into doubt whether the U.S. airline industry will be able to continue its nascent recovery.
articles.abstract: The foiled terrorist plot in London throws into doubt whether the U.S. airline industry will be able to continue its nascent recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was to be the summer the airlines were going to put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them.

articles.headline: For Californians, Deadly Heat Cut a Broad Swath
articles.snippet: A death toll in last month’s heat wave of roughly 140, the highest since 1955,  has shocked and unnerved officials.
articles.abstract: A death toll in last month’s heat wave of roughly 140, the highest since 1955,  has shocked and unnerved officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Aug. 9 — On the last day of her life, Patricia Miller-Razor did the same things she did just about every other day in this sun-parched town, even as the temperature climbed.

articles.headline: Scale and Detail of Plane Scheme Recall Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: Officials said the sophistication of the scheme could mean that Al Qaeda was behind it and was still able to direct attacks.
articles.abstract: Officials said the sophistication of the scheme could mean that Al Qaeda was behind it and was still able to direct attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intelligence and counterterrorism officials said yesterday that the scale and sophistication of the scheme to blow up jetliners over the Atlantic could mean that Al Qaeda, whose central command has been severely damaged since 2001, was again able to direct attacks.

articles.headline: Economy Often Defies Soft Landing
articles.snippet: Many economists warn that the Fed is either too rosy about the looming slowdown or naïve about the difficulty of reaching its goal for inflation.
articles.abstract: Many economists warn that the Fed is either too rosy about the looming slowdown or naïve about the difficulty of reaching its goal for inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 — In the cool and quiet marble corridors of the Federal Reserve, the strategy for taming inflation sounds painless, even soothing: a “soft landing” for the economy after several years of flying high.

articles.headline: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed in June
articles.snippet: The trade deficit reached $64.8 billion in June, modestly below the $65 billion deficit recorded for May.
articles.abstract: The trade deficit reached $64.8 billion in June, modestly below the $65 billion deficit recorded for May.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade deficit may have bottomed out.

articles.headline: Liquid Threat Is Hard to Detect
articles.snippet: Security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against liquid explosives.
articles.abstract: Security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against liquid explosives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 — Despite knowing for years that liquid explosives posed a threat to airline safety, security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against such attacks, security experts say.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Atmel’s Mess: You’re Fired. No, You Are.
articles.snippet: The situation at the Atmel Corporation never could have happened without Sarbanes-Oxley and the other reforms that followed the Enron scandal.
articles.abstract: The situation at the Atmel Corporation never could have happened without Sarbanes-Oxley and the other reforms that followed the Enron scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU can’t fire me. I’m firing you.”

articles.headline: Scale and Detail of Plane Scheme Recall Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: Intelligence and counterterrorism officials said yesterday that the scale and sophistication of the scheme to blow up jetliners over the Atlantic could mean that Al Qaeda, whose central command has been severely damaged since 2001, was again able ...
articles.abstract: Intelligence and counterterrorism officials said yesterday that the scale and sophistication of the scheme to blow up jetliners over the Atlantic could mean that Al Qaeda, whose central command has been severely damaged since 2001, was again able to direct attacks.      But some specialists on the shifting networks of international terrorism said the alternative explanation -- that homegrown British jihadists had managed to conceive a plot of such ambition -- might hold even graver implications for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intelligence and counterterrorism officials said yesterday that the scale and sophistication of the scheme to blow up jetliners over the Atlantic could mean that Al Qaeda, whose central command has been severely damaged since 2001, was again able to direct attacks.

articles.headline: Israel Asks U.S. to Ship Rockets With Wide Blast
articles.snippet: Israel has asked the Bush administration to speed delivery of short-range antipersonnel rockets armed with cluster munitions, which it could use to strike Hezbollah missile sites in Lebanon, two American officials said Thursday.     The request fo...
articles.abstract: Israel has asked the Bush administration to speed delivery of short-range antipersonnel rockets armed with cluster munitions, which it could use to strike Hezbollah missile sites in Lebanon, two American officials said Thursday.     The request for M-26 artillery rockets, which are fired in barrages and carry hundreds of grenade-like bomblets that scatter and explode over a broad area, is likely to be approved shortly, along with other arms, a senior official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 - Israel has asked the Bush administration to speed delivery of short-range antipersonnel rockets armed with cluster munitions, which it could use to strike Hezbollah missile sites in Lebanon, two American officials said Thursday.

articles.headline: Liquid Threat Is Hard to Detect
articles.snippet: Despite knowing for years that liquid explosives posed a threat to airline safety, security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against such attacks, security experts say.      Since September 2001, th...
articles.abstract: Despite knowing for years that liquid explosives posed a threat to airline safety, security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against such attacks, security experts say.      Since September 2001, the federal government has hired tens of thousands of government screeners and upgraded its metal detectors and X-ray machines. But most of the equipment is still oriented toward preventing a metallic gun or other easily identifiable weapon from being carried aboard; it cannot distinguish shampoo from an explosive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 - Despite knowing for years that liquid explosives posed a threat to airline safety, security agencies have made little progress in deploying technology that could help defend against such attacks, security experts say.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Terror Arrests Play in Political Arena
articles.snippet: Republicans seized on the arrests of terror suspects in Britain to bolster a White House campaign to turn national security issues to their advantage this fall, arguing that the nation needs tough Republican policies to protect Americans from thre...
articles.abstract: Republicans seized on the arrests of terror suspects in Britain to bolster a White House campaign to turn national security issues to their advantage this fall, arguing that the nation needs tough Republican policies to protect Americans from threats from abroad.     Democratic and Republican officials alike said they viewed the arrests as critical in determining how they would approach the fall campaign.      The developments played neatly into the White House-led effort -- after Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, was defeated in a primary on Tuesday by an antiwar challenger -- to remind voters of the threats facing the nation and to cast Democrats as timid on national security issues.   BY ADAM NAGOURNEY, PAGE A8
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans seized on the arrests of terror suspects in Britain to bolster a White House campaign to turn national security issues to their advantage this fall, arguing that the nation needs tough Republican policies to protect Americans from threats from abroad.

articles.headline: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed in June
articles.snippet: The trade deficit may have bottomed out.     The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the deficit in the nation's trade of goods and services reached $64.8 billion in June, modestly below the $65 billion deficit recorded for May.
articles.abstract: The trade deficit may have bottomed out.     The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the deficit in the nation's trade of goods and services reached $64.8 billion in June, modestly below the $65 billion deficit recorded for May.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade deficit may have bottomed out.

articles.headline: Economy Often Defies Soft Landing
articles.snippet: In the cool and quiet marble corridors of the Federal Reserve, the strategy for taming inflation sounds painless, even soothing: a ''soft landing'' for the economy after several years of flying high.     As the central bank contended on Tuesday, w...
articles.abstract: In the cool and quiet marble corridors of the Federal Reserve, the strategy for taming inflation sounds painless, even soothing: a ''soft landing'' for the economy after several years of flying high.     As the central bank contended on Tuesday, when it decided to pause in its two-year effort to raise interest rates, inflation is ''elevated'' right now but will begin to decline because economic growth is poised for a modest slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 - In the cool and quiet marble corridors of the Federal Reserve, the strategy for taming inflation sounds painless, even soothing: a "soft landing" for the economy after several years of flying high.

articles.headline: An Obstacle For Airlines
articles.snippet: This was going to be the summer that the airlines put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them. And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full and the airlines were making money again.      But the foiled terrorist plot in London ...
articles.abstract: This was going to be the summer that the airlines put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them. And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full and the airlines were making money again.      But the foiled terrorist plot in London that aimed at American carriers throws into doubt whether the airline industry will be able to continue its nascent recovery. Experts said that it was too early to tell the lasting effects of the threat, but that the industry was unlikely to escape unscathed.   BY MICHELINE MAYNARD, PAGE C1
articles.lead_paragraph: This was going to be the summer that the airlines put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them. And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full and the airlines were making money again.

articles.headline: Terror Plot Foiled; Airports Quickly Clamp Down
articles.snippet: The British authorities said Thursday that they had thwarted an advanced terrorist plot to blow up airplanes flying from Britain to the United States using liquid explosives that would have escaped airport security.     The officials said they had...
articles.abstract: The British authorities said Thursday that they had thwarted an advanced terrorist plot to blow up airplanes flying from Britain to the United States using liquid explosives that would have escaped airport security.     The officials said they had arrested 24 men, all British-born Muslims, who planned to carry the liquids in drink bottles and combine them into explosive cocktails to commit mass murder aboard as many as 10 flights high over the Atlantic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: A Brief Recovery and Now This
articles.snippet: This was to be the summer the airlines were going to put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them.      And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full -- albeit to passengers' discomfort -- and the airlines were making money again...
articles.abstract: This was to be the summer the airlines were going to put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them.      And it seemed to be working: fares were up, planes were full -- albeit to passengers' discomfort -- and the airlines were making money again. The industry just reported surprisingly strong second-quarter profit of $1.6 billion, its best showing in six years, after losing $40 billion since the 2001 terrorist attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was to be the summer the airlines were going to put 9/11 and its aftershocks firmly behind them.

articles.headline: Old Fears Resurface With News of Plot
articles.snippet: The terrorist plot, the authorities reported, was to transform ordinary things into the weaponry of mass death. With so many foiled plots lumped together in a blur of false alarms, this plot seemed to bring real fears bubbling back to the surface ...
articles.abstract: The terrorist plot, the authorities reported, was to transform ordinary things into the weaponry of mass death. With so many foiled plots lumped together in a blur of false alarms, this plot seemed to bring real fears bubbling back to the surface just when many people had started to grow numb on the subject of terrorism. That cans of what appeared to be soda could blow up a plane had a kind of mesmerizing power, prompting people to contemplate their vulnerabilities and to reflect on the limits of government to protect them.      Some took the time to praise the British authorities for their handling of the situation, while others blamed President Bush and his policies for the vulnerability of the United States.   BY JIM DWYER, PAGE A6
articles.lead_paragraph: The terrorist plot, the authorities reported, was to transform ordinary things into the weaponry of mass death. With so many foiled plots lumped together in a blur of false alarms, this plot seemed to bring real fears bubbling back to the surface just when many people had started to grow numb on the subject of terrorism. That cans of what appeared to be soda could blow up a plane had a kind of mesmerizing power, prompting people to contemplate their vulnerabilities and to reflect on the limits of government to protect them.

articles.headline: At Airports, a Day of Getting Through
articles.snippet: For millions of passengers, airline employees and security workers, it was a day of getting through, getting by and hoping for the best. Long security lines, missed flights, delayed departures, harried workers and annoyed people of every stripe we...
articles.abstract: For millions of passengers, airline employees and security workers, it was a day of getting through, getting by and hoping for the best. Long security lines, missed flights, delayed departures, harried workers and annoyed people of every stripe were common in airports across the country as tightened security rules rattled the nation's air system amid new details on a reported terror plot to bring down planes between Britain and the United States.   BY KIRK JOHNSON, PAGE A9
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of passengers, airline employees and security workers, it was a day of getting through, getting by and hoping for the best. Long security lines, missed flights, delayed departures, harried workers and annoyed people of every stripe were common in airports across the country as tightened security rules rattled the nation's air system amid new details on a reported terror plot to bring down planes between Britain and the United States. BY KIRK JOHNSON, PAGE A9

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Manager Who Plays His Cards Right
articles.snippet: As a hedge fund manager, David Einhorn might be expected to be a typical competitive poker player.     Except that he doesn't play a lot of poker.
articles.abstract: As a hedge fund manager, David Einhorn might be expected to be a typical competitive poker player.     Except that he doesn't play a lot of poker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: For Californians, Deadly Heat Cut a Broad Swath
articles.snippet: On the last day of her life, Patricia Miller-Razor did the same things she did just about every other day in this sun-parched town, even as the temperature climbed.     She wrapped herself in her signature sweatsuit. She rode her bicycle to the Gr...
articles.abstract: On the last day of her life, Patricia Miller-Razor did the same things she did just about every other day in this sun-parched town, even as the temperature climbed.     She wrapped herself in her signature sweatsuit. She rode her bicycle to the Green Frog Market. She pondered her oil paintings, and carvings fashioned from avocado seeds, all the while refusing the entreaties from her family to flick on her cooler in her sweltering house.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Aug. 9 - On the last day of her life, Patricia Miller-Razor did the same things she did just about every other day in this sun-parched town, even as the temperature climbed.

articles.headline: Atmel’s Mess: You’re Fired. No, You Are.
articles.snippet: ''YOU can't fire me. I'm firing you.''     Many terminated employees may have dreamed of saying that. But of course, such a thing cannot happen.
articles.abstract: ''YOU can't fire me. I'm firing you.''     Many terminated employees may have dreamed of saying that. But of course, such a thing cannot happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: "YOU can't fire me. I'm firing you."
